 onerror="this.style.display='none'" /> </a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></header><div id="et-main-area"><div id="main-content"><div class="et-l et-l--body"><div class="et_builder_inner_content et_pb_gutters3"><div class="et_pb_section et_pb_section_0_tb_body et_pb_with_background et_section_regular section_has_divider et_pb_bottom_divider" ><div class="et_pb_row et_pb_row_0_tb_body et_pb_equal_columns"><div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_4_4 et_pb_column_0_tb_body  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough et-last-child"><div class="et_pb_module et_pb_post_title et_pb_post_title_0_tb_body et_pb_bg_layout_light  et_pb_text_align_left"   ><div class="et_pb_title_container"><h1 class="entry-title">Learning Academies: Where Corporations Optimize their L&D</h1></div></div></div></div><div class="et_pb_bottom_inside_divider et-no-transition"></div></div><div class="et_pb_section et_pb_section_1_tb_body et_section_regular" ><div class="et_pb_row et_pb_row_1_tb_body et_pb_gutters3"><div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_4_4 et_pb_column_1_tb_body  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough et-last-child"><div class="et_pb_module et_pb_post_content et_pb_post_content_0_tb_body"><div class="et-l et-l--post"><div class="et_builder_inner_content et_pb_gutters3"><div class="et_pb_section et_pb_section_0 et_section_regular" ><div class="et_pb_row et_pb_row_0"><div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_4_4 et_pb_column_0  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough et-last-child"><div class="et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_0  et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light"><div class="et_pb_text_inner"><p>Corporate training is constantly evolving, and part of that is down to the rise of corporate universities and learning academies. In 2025, we predict that learning academies will become increasingly prominent in the L&D space, which will alter the way our employees, partners, and customers learn new skills and develop new behaviors.</p><p>In this post, we’ll take a look at what a learning academy is, why they’re so beneficial, and why we think they’re going to become an important part of corporate learning in 2025 and beyond!</p><ul><li><a href="#part-1">What is a learning academy?</a></li><li><a href="#part-2">What problems can learning academies help businesses solve?</a></li><li><a href="#part-3">Who should invest in establishing a learning academy?</a></li><li><a href="#part-4">How to establish a learning academy</a></li><li><a href="#part-5">Challenges when running learning academies</a></li><li><a href="#part-6">Bottom line</a></li></ul><h2 id="part-1">What is a learning academy?</h2><p>A <strong>learning academy</strong> is a specific training and development program designed by a corporation’s L&D team to enhance the skills, knowledge, and competencies of its employees, customers, and extended enterprise.</p><p>Learning academies may also be branded as a skills academy, training academy, or even more specifically, a <strong>corporate training academy</strong>. Nonetheless, a learning academy provides various learning programs in various topics from leadership and organizational management to compliance training and technical skills development.</p><p>The modern learning academy has two primary objectives in modern business:</p><ol><li>To equip employees with in-demand skills to advance the service offerings of the organization.</li><li>To strengthen and refine the professional skill sets of those who work for the organization.</li></ol><p>Alongside web-based eLearning courses, learning academies often have courses delivered via traditional face-to-face <strong>instructor-led training</strong>, <strong>virtual instructor-led training</strong>, or a combination of the two that extend beyond an office setting.</p><p><img decoding="async" src="https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/LearningAcademies_FeaturedImage.png" width="1200" height="628" alt="" class="wp-image-25818473 alignnone size-full" srcset="https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/LearningAcademies_FeaturedImage.png 1200w, https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/LearningAcademies_FeaturedImage-980x513.png 980w, https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/LearningAcademies_FeaturedImage-480x251.png 480w" sizes="(min-width: 0px) and (max-width: 480px) 480px, (min-width: 481px) and (max-width: 980px) 980px, (min-width: 981px) 1200px, 100vw" /></p><h2 id="part-2">What problems can learning academies help businesses solve?</h2><p>It would be foolish to think that a learning academy is just a fancy label for an organization’s L&D department. It’s actually much deeper than that!</p><p>Think of the learning academy as not just internal training, but also the talent consulting branch of an organization. It harbors deep expertise and understanding of everything about an organization’s learning, from creating the learning itself to measuring the impact and establishing the link between training and talent development.</p><p>On top of the two objectives listed above, a learning academy has two primary missions in today’s corporate workplace:</p><ol><li><strong>To address talent shortages due to the widening skills gap</strong></li><li><strong>To align L&D objectives with business objectives</strong></li></ol><p>Both missions have been elusive for the L&D industry for several years. Let’s take a deeper dive into each.</p><h3><strong>Problem #1:</strong> The ever-present skills gap and talent shortage</h3><p>Talent and technology have grown inversely in the past decade with the growth of automation tech and the explosion of AI-fueled processes.</p><p>One stark account from the World Economic Forum in 2020 predicted that at its current pace, technology will remove <strong>85 million jobs,</strong> but also <a href="https://www.weforum.org/press/2020/10/recession-and-automation-changes-our-future-of-work-but-there-are-jobs-coming-report-says-52c5162fce/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>create 97 million new jobs</strong></a> in the process.</p><p>On top of this, McKinsey & Company reported a whopping <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/five-fifty-the-skillful-corporation" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>87% of companies</strong></a> are experiencing a need for talent in key areas of the business. With increased job displacement caused by new technology, <strong>6 in 10 workers</strong> will need to be retrained and reskilled.</p><p>Combine these eye-opening statistics with the fact that the global L&D industry spends close to <strong><a href="https://trainingindustry.com/wiki/learning-services-and-outsourcing/size-of-training-industry/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">$358 billion</a></strong>, most of which is on learning software and outsourced training services, and it’s easy to see why organizations are so eager to close these growing skills gaps – and fast.</p><p>Despite the massive boom of <a href="https://www.statista.com/statistics/1130331/e-learning-market-size-segment-worldwide/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>learning management systems (LMSs) and other eLearning software in 2019</strong></a>, businesses have been able to provide more training at scale but have still fallen short of developing talent with the hard and soft skills needed in the workplace.</p><h3><strong>Solution #1:</strong> Learning academies are designed to develop and retain talent</h3><p>The global skills gap is a problem that learning academies are perfectly positioned to solve. Why? Learning academies have an excellent track record for onboarding, upskilling, and reskilling professionals.</p><p>With a dedicated corporate faculty of qualified instructors to lead employees, learners are guided with the skills they need to make both the company and their careers a success.</p><p>Historically, the academy model is a prototype for successful L&D delivery. Previously known as <strong>corporate universities </strong>or <strong>corporate academies,</strong> the “CorpU” campus became the traditional brick-and-mortar institution within an institution designed to establish excellence in its employees.</p><p>From the <strong><a href="https://slate.com/business/2014/06/ges-crotonville-management-campus-where-future-company-leaders-are-trained.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first corporate academy by General Electric</a></strong> to the growth of <strong><a href="https://www.mcdonalds.com/qa/en-qa/career_mcd/training-and-education.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hamburger University by McDonald’s</a></strong> in the mid-1990s, corporations have long understood that learning and development needs an established curriculum and expert guidance.</p><p>Instructor-led training (ILT) was a hugely important part of the corporate university for onboarding new talent and delivering crucial training via traditional face-to-face instruction. ILT was a key driver in the success of the original wave of corporate universities, long before the rise of the LMS and eLearning we see today.</p><p>Carrying this model to the present day, modern technology has allowed various enterprise organizations to develop and adapt their learning academies to support each of their business’ service divisions.</p><p>However, that hasn’t made ILT (or Virtual Instructor-Led Training, also known as VILT) any less important. Today’s most successful learning academies feature a powerful blend of ILT, VILT, on-demand eLearning, and resource libraries, tailored to the needs of the specific sector and learners.</p><p>Leading learning analyst Josh Bersin has come to reevaluate corporate learning academies as the <a href="https://joshbersin.com/2021/07/what-is-a-capability-academy-heres-the-answer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>capability academy</strong></a>. This new learning academy for corporations is a multi-functional machine aiming to excel in L&D for organizations using more than just instructor-led learning.</p><p>To quote Josh Bersin directly, these specialized L&D units “are designed to build skills-based capability academies; they group large audiences into small cohorts; and they integrate content with <strong><em>live events</em></strong>, assignments, <em><strong>collaboration</strong></em>, mentors, and experts. And they can deliver all this at scale.”</p><p>A combination of focus-group learning, engaging instructor-led training, and hybrid learning in the workplace helps establish a positive learning experience that produces real business results.</p><p><strong>Discover More: <a href="/7-employee-development-programs/">The 7 Employee Development Programs to Grow Your Business</a></strong></p><h3><strong>Problem #2:</strong> Connecting L&D with business goals</h3><p>In addition to talent fluctuations, L&D and HR teams have long had an issue establishing the purpose of learning initiatives within business objectives. Simply put: what’s the reason why a particular training course is important, and how does it make the company more successful? Even more to consider, how does it contribute towards the professional growth of the learners?</p><p>Since growing a staggering <strong>900%</strong> since 2000, the eLearning provider industry now comprises <strong>6,582 companies </strong>that provide a wide range of services. With so many learning providers, one would think L&D and organizational goals have been met. Well, not quite.</p><p>The issue with eLearning, however, is that it doesn’t provide transparency on how the training is improving business. According to a study by Brandon Hall Group, corporate learning strategies have become misaligned, with <strong>87% of respondents</strong> reporting that there is <a href="https://brandonhall.com/aligning-the-ld-strategy-with-business-goals/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>no clear link between L&D and company strategy</strong></a>. Employees may naturally think, “This is a mandatory course, so chances are it’ll be relevant to my job” but that isn’t always the case. Employees aren’t given a clear understanding of how useful it’ll be on the job, or even their career, which leaves the value of learning and the wider business goals feeling disconnected.</p><h3><strong>Solution #2:</strong> Learning academies clarify the link between learning and business objectives</h3><p>Clarifying the impact of training has been the biggest challenge for L&D teams in recent years. Another study by the Brandon Hall Group on the modern <a href="https://brandonhall.com/is-maintaining-a-learning-strategy-and-a-learning-council-worth-the-effort/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>corporate learning strategy</strong></a> revealed that <strong>70%</strong> of organizations have not identified learning goals, with an additional<strong> 67%</strong> saying they cannot measure the effectiveness of their training. If we don’t know <em>why </em>we’re offering training, why <em>are </em>we offering it in the first place?</p><p>Corporate learning academies function like any other department within an organization. According to Josh Bersin’s analysis, “<a href="https://joshbersin.com/2021/07/what-is-a-capability-academy-heres-the-answer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>learning academies should be led by a business leader that’s not just an L&D professional</strong></a>”. Because of this, it makes sense why learning academies are led by the <a href="/chief-learning-officer/"><strong>chief learning officer</strong></a> and staffed with an entire group of L&D professionals. Combining the seat at the C-suite table with the expertise of the L&D team connects the corporate vision with the corporate learning strategy, making it crystal clear <em>why </em>the learning exists and <em>what benefits </em>the business can expect as a result.</p><h2 id="part-3">Who should invest in establishing a learning academy?</h2><p>Businesses large and small that are looking to deliver rapid training and get real results should consider establishing a learning academy to help streamline <a href="/learning-operations/"><strong>learning operations</strong></a>. It may seem that only large-scale companies have the budget and resources to establish learning academies, but don’t be fooled! You may not need to be big to start, but you’ll need to start to be big!</p><p>Some of the most successful corporate learning academies include:</p><ul><li>AT&T: Technology Academy</li><li>Capital One: Cloud, Digital, and Cybersecurity Academy</li><li>Comcast: Academy of Customer Service</li><li>Citi: Citi Client Service Academy</li><li>Comex: Supply Chain Academy and Safety Academy</li><li>Ford: Autonomous Vehicle Academy</li><li>Maersk: Procurement & Logistics Academy</li><li>Morgan Stanley: Small Business Academy</li><li>Visa: FinTech Capability Academy</li></ul><p>From the early days of the corporate university to the modern “capability academy” that Bersin suggests, learning academies are the perfect fit for organizations that are serious about developing professional talent to meet company goals – regardless of size, sector, or location. It is only with a deep understanding of the audience that organizations can create the right blend of ILT, eLearning, on-demand resources, assessments, and more to ensure that the academy is impactful and achieves everything it needs to.</p><p>An established learning academy shows employees, partners, and even <a href="/what-is-customer-training-how-to-manage-it/"><strong>customers</strong></a> that they are serious about investing in training to meet business objectives and to be an organization that prioritizes not only the performance of their product but also the team that makes it a success.</p><p><img decoding="async" src="https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/ManLearningOnline.jpg" width="1255" height="835" alt="" class="wp-image-25818480 size-full" srcset="https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/ManLearningOnline.jpg 1255w, https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/ManLearningOnline-980x652.jpg 980w, https://trainingorchestra.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/ManLearningOnline-480x319.jpg 480w" sizes="(min-width: 0px) and (max-width: 480px) 480px, (min-width: 481px) and (max-width: 980px) 980px, (min-width: 981px) 1255px, 100vw" /></p><h2 id="part-4">How to establish a learning academy</h2><p>For training teams and L&D departments, the idea of setting up a learning academy may seem like a daunting endeavor with so many variables in play. However, with proper planning and execution and the right technology in place, establishing a learning academy may not be as difficult as you may think. If you’re seriously considering launching a learning academy in 2025, we’ve created a handy step-by-step guide outlining the tasks you’ll need to complete.</p><h3>1. Define the learning academy’s mission for both learners and the business</h3><p>The goal of all learning academies in the corporate space is to promote the value of skills development with both organizational success and professional development. Here, L&D professionals and C-level executives must 100% agree that the learning academy and its distinct training programs are to develop professionals with applicable and beneficial skills.</p><h3>2. Setting Training Milestones and Targets</h3><p>While it doesn’t have to be perfect, establishing a roadmap for your learning academy can help pave the way for successful training. Some key questions L&D teams can ask themselves can help guide milestone setting can be:</p><ul><li><strong>What are the skills that we want to develop within the entire organization?</strong></li><li><strong>How can we increase engagement and enrollment within the learning academy?</strong></li><li><strong>What are the red flags to look for when courses are deployed for instructors and learners?</strong></li></ul><h3>3. Develop your learning academy’s course curriculum</h3><p>The course curriculum serves as your learning academy’s blueprint for the different training programs it will offer.</p><p>It should detail the individual course offerings, including what skillsets or subjects will be taught. The course curriculum should be guided by the learning goals and business objectives agreed upon with your C-suite and L&D team in Step 1.</p><p>For example, if you’re looking to increase your team’s lead generation and profitability, you may look to implement a curriculum focused on <a href="/sales-enablement-training/"><strong>sales enablement training</strong></a> that focuses on client communication and product training.</p><h3>4. Strategize on your learning delivery channels</h3><p>Think carefully about the composition of your learning academy. Will it be exclusively eLearning, or will you enhance the experience with <a href="/training-management-challenges/ilt-and-vilt-management/"><strong>ILT and VILT</strong></a>?</p><p>Regardless, make sure you secure the buy-in of your senior stakeholders including subject matter experts and the instructors to secure resources and any staff involvement.</p><p>Once you know what you want your learning academy to look like, you get an idea of what resources, <a href="/training-management-challenges/training-cost-management-financial-performance/"><strong>training budget</strong></a>, and timelines you’ll need to make it happen. Different modes of training delivery have different requirements.</p><p>For instance, in-person instructor-led training generally requires a bigger budget and involves more complex logistics due to the need for classrooms and equipment; virtual instructor-led training can be more feasible as long as all participants have an internet connection at the very least.</p><h3>5. Define success metrics for your learning initiative</h3><p>When you know what success will look like, think about the metrics you can use to measure this. This is about more than just vanity metrics (such as course completions or platform logins) – it’s about how your learning academy impacts business performance according to your organizational goals.</p><p>For instance, is your focus on utilizing the learning academy to improve talent retention or focus more on professional development with programs more focused on <a href="/4-ways-ld-can-lead-reskilling-upskilling/"><strong>upskilling and reskilling</strong></a>?</p><p>And what is your threshold for success? For example, you could say that you want to improve talent retention by 20%, so think about how you can measure this, and what your timeframe looks like.</p><p><strong>Discover More: <a href="/training-management-system/reporting-and-analytics/">Measuring Learning Initiatives with Training Orchestra</a></strong></p><h3>6. Assemble a corporate training team</h3><p>With your plans, mission, and goals in place, it’s time to assemble your corporate training dream team. This team should comprise internal managers, directors, executives, and external professional trainers and professors at a minimum.</p><p>Each trainer should be hand-picked as an excellent communicator for both ILT and VILT delivery to ensure that the learning academy experience is elevated above standard corporate training.</p><p>This is the time to pull out the best of the best – after all, learning academies are a big investment of time, budget, and effort, so you only want the most experienced, engaging trainers to bring your vision to life!</p><h3>7. Align the curriculum with the company’s industry and services</h3><p>Here’s where it pays to understand your business inside out. Aligning your courses, content, and learning activities with your organization’s culture and goals, alongside those of the wider industry, will help you build a learning academy that resonates with your learners.</p><p>For instance, a learning academy for <strong><a href="/industries/financial-services/">financial services</a></strong> workers will feel very different from a learning academy for <a href="/industries/hospitals-and-healthcare/"><strong>healthcare</strong></a> employees, who are likely to prefer more in-person ILT, so make sure it makes sense within the context of your business.</p><p>On that note, choose delivery methods that suit your learners and use suitable technology to enhance the learning experience. As an example, <strong><a href="/industries/transportation-and-logistics/">transportation and logistics</a></strong> workers who rarely sit at their desks may come to find a blended learning approach may be more beneficial.</p><p>On the contrary, <a href="/training-management-for-medical-devices/"><strong>medical device manufacturers</strong></a> may prefer a more hands-on approach that’s normally found in instructor-led training-based sessions.</p><h3>8. Select qualified and available training providers</h3><p>Qualified instructors and trainers are what orchestrate a winning experience for learning academies. As subject-matter experts in their fields, trainers who check all the boxes for instructing learners can turn the most routine course material into an engaging and intellectually stimulating session.</p><p>When selecting instructors for ILT or VILT sessions, be sure that they can meet every standard for your training program. From the language of instruction and time-zone coverage to the learner-approved qualities of a good instructor.</p><h3>9. Don’t forget certification programs!</h3><p>The best learning academies offer certifications that demonstrate proficiency in a core set of skills. Certifications should be from recognized associations that are from the de jure leaders in their field. For example, People & Culture specialists should aim to receive certs from the Human Resources Certification Institute allowing employees to work toward a certificate to prove their attainment.</p><p>Your learning academy team must also have a process in place to make sure that certifications are valid and that expiration dates are noted. Don’t forget to ensure your learners can promote their certification on social media! Besides, who doesn’t like a badge certifying their expertise in a specific ability?</p><h3>10. Promote the benefits of the learning academy</h3><p>“If you build it, they will come” sadly doesn’t apply in the world of corporate training. Work with your marketing team, and develop a strategy to get employees excited about the opportunities the learning academy can provide in advancing their development and involvement in the organization. You can even take it a stretch further by promoting your learning academy with partners in your <a href="/training-management-software-for-extended-enterprise/"><strong>extended enterprise</strong></a> that are looking to augment their skills. It’s a win-win for everyone!</p><h3>11. Create a detailed rollout plan</h3><p>Once you’re ready to go live, you’ll need a detailed rollout plan to ensure the smooth implementation of your learning academy. This should cover everything from the email and communications plan to creating ambassadors across the business to help encourage enrollment.</p><p>This should extend into the first few months after the launch, at which point you can take the first measurements and reassess your promotion plan going forward. Assigning a named owner to each area will help maintain accountability and keep everything moving at the right pace.</p><h2 id="part-5">Challenges for running learning academies</h2><p>We don’t want to pretend that running a learning academy is easy. It’s a much bigger undertaking than your standard training course, and it requires ongoing commitment from the entire L&D team.</p><p>Some of the key challenges to be aware of when setting up and running learning academies include:</p><ul><li>Understanding the skills needs of your learners and translating them into an actionable course can make it difficult even with a training needs analysis.</li><li>The costs of running a learning academy can be expensive depending on the scope. General Electric’s <strong><a href="https://hrexecutive.com/the-end-of-ges-crotonville-what-it-says-about-ld/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Crotonville Learning Institute</a></strong> cost almost $1 billion in management costs.</li><li>Managing the logistics of a learning academy is more complex as it has several training programs that can have a significant size and scope of resources</li><li>Managing in-person ILT and online VILT <strong><a href="/scaling-training-without-spreadsheets/">course scheduling with spreadsheets</a></strong> can quickly prove to be inefficient and a hassle for your learning academy team.</li></ul><h2 id="part-6">Bottom line: investing in learning academies means investing in your business growth</h2><p>As corporate training initiatives grow in importance, learning academies are set to make a comeback for businesses looking to grow and optimize their services. If you’re thinking about developing your learning academy, you must go in with a clear action plan with measurable goals and a deep understanding of your learners’ needs.</p><p>A highly effective learning academy requires a blend of eLearning content, on-demand resources, and live ILT or VILT sessions. While asynchronous online learning will help learners access what they need and provide them the opportunity to do it at their own pace, practical skill sets that are used for specific job roles will be best served with ILT and VILT.</p><p>Integrating ILT and VILT into your learning academies will help learners make useful connections with their peers, get hands-on with their training, and engage in memorable experiences with inspiring trainers. What’s important, though, is choosing the right technology to help you deliver top-quality live learning experiences with minimal manual effort.</p><h2>The platform designed for learning academy teams</h2><p>Running a learning academy isn’t an easy endeavor even for the most experienced L&D professionals. To execute your learning academy strategy that delivers the best in-person training you’re going to need a platform that can manage all aspects of the operation.</p><p>That’s where Training Orchestra comes in. A tool specialized in delivering ILT and VILT experiences, our <a href="/training-management-system/"><strong>training management system</strong></a> (TMS) is perfectly positioned to support learning academies looking to drive an engaging learning experience with instructor-led training.</p><p>With Training Orchestra, learning academy teams have a centralized dashboard that allows them to schedule live training sessions, source and assign instructors, stay on top of their training budgets, and even manage communication channels. It integrates seamlessly with most LMS platforms and can help complement your learning academy’s blended learning approach to training.</p><p>Thinking about launching a learning academy to optimize your corporate L&D? We’d love to help!</p><p><a href="/demo/"><strong>Get in touch toda</strong>y</a> to find out how Training Orchestra can help you streamline the training operations for your learning academy in 2025 and beyond.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="et_pb_section et_pb_section_3_tb_body et_pb_with_background et_section_regular" ><div class="et_pb_row et_pb_row_2_tb_body"><div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_1_2 et_pb_column_2_tb_body  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough"><div class="et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_0_tb_body checklist-bullet-list-2  et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light"><div class="et_pb_text_inner"><h2>Book a Training Orchestra TMS demo now</h2><p>Find out how to simplify your complex training operations so you can deliver more training with less:</p><ul><li style="padding-bottom: 10px; padding-top: 15px;"><strong>Experience the leading TMS platform</strong> trusted by companies worldwide</li><li style="padding-bottom: 10px;"><strong>Explore use cases</strong> for your organization's specific needs</li><li style="padding-bottom: 10px;"><strong>See how to boost productivity</strong> for your training delivery team</li></ul></div></div></div><div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_1_2 et_pb_column_3_tb_body  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough et-last-child"><div class="et_pb_module et_pb_code et_pb_code_0_tb_body"><div class="et_pb_code_inner"><script charset="utf-8" type="text/javascript" src="//js.hsforms.net/forms/embed/v2.js"></script> <script> hbspt.forms.create({

data.text:
Corporate training is constantly evolving, and part of that is down to the rise of corporate universities and learning academies. In 2025, we predict that learning academies will become increasingly prominent in the L&D space, which will alter the way our employees, partners, and customers learn new skills and develop new behaviors.
In this post, we’ll take a look at what a learning academy is, why they’re so beneficial, and why we think they’re going to become an important part of corporate learning in 2025 and beyond!
[What is a learning academy?](#part-1)[What problems can learning academies help businesses solve?](#part-2)[Who should invest in establishing a learning academy?](#part-3)[How to establish a learning academy](#part-4)[Challenges when running learning academies](#part-5)[Bottom line](#part-6)
What is a learning academy?
A learning academy is a specific training and development program designed by a corporation’s L&D team to enhance the skills, knowledge, and competencies of its employees, customers, and extended enterprise.
Learning academies may also be branded as a skills academy, training academy, or even more specifically, a corporate training academy. Nonetheless, a learning academy provides various learning programs in various topics from leadership and organizational management to compliance training and technical skills development.
The modern learning academy has two primary objectives in modern business:
- To equip employees with in-demand skills to advance the service offerings of the organization.
- To strengthen and refine the professional skill sets of those who work for the organization.
Alongside web-based eLearning courses, learning academies often have courses delivered via traditional face-to-face instructor-led training, virtual instructor-led training, or a combination of the two that extend beyond an office setting.
What problems can learning academies help businesses solve?
It would be foolish to think that a learning academy is just a fancy label for an organization’s L&D department. It’s actually much deeper than that!
Think of the learning academy as not just internal training, but also the talent consulting branch of an organization. It harbors deep expertise and understanding of everything about an organization’s learning, from creating the learning itself to measuring the impact and establishing the link between training and talent development.
On top of the two objectives listed above, a learning academy has two primary missions in today’s corporate workplace:
- To address talent shortages due to the widening skills gap
- To align L&D objectives with business objectives
Both missions have been elusive for the L&D industry for several years. Let’s take a deeper dive into each.
Problem #1: The ever-present skills gap and talent shortage
Talent and technology have grown inversely in the past decade with the growth of automation tech and the explosion of AI-fueled processes.
One stark account from the World Economic Forum in 2020 predicted that at its current pace, technology will remove 85 million jobs, but also [create 97 million new jobs](https://www.weforum.org/press/2020/10/recession-and-automation-changes-our-future-of-work-but-there-are-jobs-coming-report-says-52c5162fce/) in the process.
On top of this, McKinsey & Company reported a whopping [87% of companies](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/five-fifty-the-skillful-corporation) are experiencing a need for talent in key areas of the business. With increased job displacement caused by new technology, 6 in 10 workers will need to be retrained and reskilled.
Combine these eye-opening statistics with the fact that the global L&D industry spends close to [$358 billion](https://trainingindustry.com/wiki/learning-services-and-outsourcing/size-of-training-industry/), most of which is on learning software and outsourced training services, and it’s easy to see why organizations are so eager to close these growing skills gaps – and fast.
Despite the massive boom of [learning management systems (LMSs) and other eLearning software in 2019](https://www.statista.com/statistics/1130331/e-learning-market-size-segment-worldwide/), businesses have been able to provide more training at scale but have still fallen short of developing talent with the hard and soft skills needed in the workplace.
Solution #1: Learning academies are designed to develop and retain talent
The global skills gap is a problem that learning academies are perfectly positioned to solve. Why? Learning academies have an excellent track record for onboarding, upskilling, and reskilling professionals.
With a dedicated corporate faculty of qualified instructors to lead employees, learners are guided with the skills they need to make both the company and their careers a success.
Historically, the academy model is a prototype for successful L&D delivery. Previously known as corporate universities or corporate academies, the “CorpU” campus became the traditional brick-and-mortar institution within an institution designed to establish excellence in its employees.
From the [first corporate academy by General Electric](https://slate.com/business/2014/06/ges-crotonville-management-campus-where-future-company-leaders-are-trained.html) to the growth of [Hamburger University by McDonald’s](https://www.mcdonalds.com/qa/en-qa/career_mcd/training-and-education.html) in the mid-1990s, corporations have long understood that learning and development needs an established curriculum and expert guidance.
Instructor-led training (ILT) was a hugely important part of the corporate university for onboarding new talent and delivering crucial training via traditional face-to-face instruction. ILT was a key driver in the success of the original wave of corporate universities, long before the rise of the LMS and eLearning we see today.
Carrying this model to the present day, modern technology has allowed various enterprise organizations to develop and adapt their learning academies to support each of their business’ service divisions.
However, that hasn’t made ILT (or Virtual Instructor-Led Training, also known as VILT) any less important. Today’s most successful learning academies feature a powerful blend of ILT, VILT, on-demand eLearning, and resource libraries, tailored to the needs of the specific sector and learners.
Leading learning analyst Josh Bersin has come to reevaluate corporate learning academies as the [capability academy](https://joshbersin.com/2021/07/what-is-a-capability-academy-heres-the-answer/). This new learning academy for corporations is a multi-functional machine aiming to excel in L&D for organizations using more than just instructor-led learning.
To quote Josh Bersin directly, these specialized L&D units “are designed to build skills-based capability academies; they group large audiences into small cohorts; and they integrate content with live events, assignments, collaboration, mentors, and experts. And they can deliver all this at scale.”
A combination of focus-group learning, engaging instructor-led training, and hybrid learning in the workplace helps establish a positive learning experience that produces real business results.

Problem #2: Connecting L&D with business goals
In addition to talent fluctuations, L&D and HR teams have long had an issue establishing the purpose of learning initiatives within business objectives. Simply put: what’s the reason why a particular training course is important, and how does it make the company more successful? Even more to consider, how does it contribute towards the professional growth of the learners?
Since growing a staggering 900% since 2000, the eLearning provider industry now comprises 6,582 companies that provide a wide range of services. With so many learning providers, one would think L&D and organizational goals have been met. Well, not quite.
The issue with eLearning, however, is that it doesn’t provide transparency on how the training is improving business. According to a study by Brandon Hall Group, corporate learning strategies have become misaligned, with 87% of respondents reporting that there is [no clear link between L&D and company strategy](https://brandonhall.com/aligning-the-ld-strategy-with-business-goals/). Employees may naturally think, “This is a mandatory course, so chances are it’ll be relevant to my job” but that isn’t always the case. Employees aren’t given a clear understanding of how useful it’ll be on the job, or even their career, which leaves the value of learning and the wider business goals feeling disconnected.
Solution #2: Learning academies clarify the link between learning and business objectives
Clarifying the impact of training has been the biggest challenge for L&D teams in recent years. Another study by the Brandon Hall Group on the modern [corporate learning strategy](https://brandonhall.com/is-maintaining-a-learning-strategy-and-a-learning-council-worth-the-effort/) revealed that 70% of organizations have not identified learning goals, with an additional 67% saying they cannot measure the effectiveness of their training. If we don’t know why we’re offering training, why are we offering it in the first place?
Corporate learning academies function like any other department within an organization. According to Josh Bersin’s analysis, “[learning academies should be led by a business leader that’s not just an L&D professional](https://joshbersin.com/2021/07/what-is-a-capability-academy-heres-the-answer/)”. Because of this, it makes sense why learning academies are led by the [chief learning officer](/chief-learning-officer/) and staffed with an entire group of L&D professionals. Combining the seat at the C-suite table with the expertise of the L&D team connects the corporate vision with the corporate learning strategy, making it crystal clear why the learning exists and what benefits the business can expect as a result.
Who should invest in establishing a learning academy?
Businesses large and small that are looking to deliver rapid training and get real results should consider establishing a learning academy to help streamline [learning operations](/learning-operations/). It may seem that only large-scale companies have the budget and resources to establish learning academies, but don’t be fooled! You may not need to be big to start, but you’ll need to start to be big!
Some of the most successful corporate learning academies include:
- AT&T: Technology Academy
- Capital One: Cloud, Digital, and Cybersecurity Academy
- Comcast: Academy of Customer Service
- Citi: Citi Client Service Academy
- Comex: Supply Chain Academy and Safety Academy
- Ford: Autonomous Vehicle Academy
- Maersk: Procurement & Logistics Academy
- Morgan Stanley: Small Business Academy
- Visa: FinTech Capability Academy
From the early days of the corporate university to the modern “capability academy” that Bersin suggests, learning academies are the perfect fit for organizations that are serious about developing professional talent to meet company goals – regardless of size, sector, or location. It is only with a deep understanding of the audience that organizations can create the right blend of ILT, eLearning, on-demand resources, assessments, and more to ensure that the academy is impactful and achieves everything it needs to.
An established learning academy shows employees, partners, and even [customers](/what-is-customer-training-how-to-manage-it/) that they are serious about investing in training to meet business objectives and to be an organization that prioritizes not only the performance of their product but also the team that makes it a success.
How to establish a learning academy
For training teams and L&D departments, the idea of setting up a learning academy may seem like a daunting endeavor with so many variables in play. However, with proper planning and execution and the right technology in place, establishing a learning academy may not be as difficult as you may think. If you’re seriously considering launching a learning academy in 2025, we’ve created a handy step-by-step guide outlining the tasks you’ll need to complete.
1. Define the learning academy’s mission for both learners and the business
The goal of all learning academies in the corporate space is to promote the value of skills development with both organizational success and professional development. Here, L&D professionals and C-level executives must 100% agree that the learning academy and its distinct training programs are to develop professionals with applicable and beneficial skills.
2. Setting Training Milestones and Targets
While it doesn’t have to be perfect, establishing a roadmap for your learning academy can help pave the way for successful training. Some key questions L&D teams can ask themselves can help guide milestone setting can be:
- What are the skills that we want to develop within the entire organization?
- How can we increase engagement and enrollment within the learning academy?
- What are the red flags to look for when courses are deployed for instructors and learners?
3. Develop your learning academy’s course curriculum
The course curriculum serves as your learning academy’s blueprint for the different training programs it will offer.
It should detail the individual course offerings, including what skillsets or subjects will be taught. The course curriculum should be guided by the learning goals and business objectives agreed upon with your C-suite and L&D team in Step 1.
For example, if you’re looking to increase your team’s lead generation and profitability, you may look to implement a curriculum focused on [sales enablement training](/sales-enablement-training/) that focuses on client communication and product training.
4. Strategize on your learning delivery channels
Think carefully about the composition of your learning academy. Will it be exclusively eLearning, or will you enhance the experience with [ILT and VILT](/training-management-challenges/ilt-and-vilt-management/)?
Regardless, make sure you secure the buy-in of your senior stakeholders including subject matter experts and the instructors to secure resources and any staff involvement.
Once you know what you want your learning academy to look like, you get an idea of what resources, [training budget](/training-management-challenges/training-cost-management-financial-performance/), and timelines you’ll need to make it happen. Different modes of training delivery have different requirements.
For instance, in-person instructor-led training generally requires a bigger budget and involves more complex logistics due to the need for classrooms and equipment; virtual instructor-led training can be more feasible as long as all participants have an internet connection at the very least.
5. Define success metrics for your learning initiative
When you know what success will look like, think about the metrics you can use to measure this. This is about more than just vanity metrics (such as course completions or platform logins) – it’s about how your learning academy impacts business performance according to your organizational goals.
For instance, is your focus on utilizing the learning academy to improve talent retention or focus more on professional development with programs more focused on [upskilling and reskilling](/4-ways-ld-can-lead-reskilling-upskilling/)?
And what is your threshold for success? For example, you could say that you want to improve talent retention by 20%, so think about how you can measure this, and what your timeframe looks like.
Discover More: [Measuring Learning Initiatives with Training Orchestra](/training-management-system/reporting-and-analytics/)
6. Assemble a corporate training team
With your plans, mission, and goals in place, it’s time to assemble your corporate training dream team. This team should comprise internal managers, directors, executives, and external professional trainers and professors at a minimum.
Each trainer should be hand-picked as an excellent communicator for both ILT and VILT delivery to ensure that the learning academy experience is elevated above standard corporate training.
This is the time to pull out the best of the best – after all, learning academies are a big investment of time, budget, and effort, so you only want the most experienced, engaging trainers to bring your vision to life!
7. Align the curriculum with the company’s industry and services
Here’s where it pays to understand your business inside out. Aligning your courses, content, and learning activities with your organization’s culture and goals, alongside those of the wider industry, will help you build a learning academy that resonates with your learners.
For instance, a learning academy for [financial services](/industries/financial-services/) workers will feel very different from a learning academy for [healthcare](/industries/hospitals-and-healthcare/) employees, who are likely to prefer more in-person ILT, so make sure it makes sense within the context of your business.
On that note, choose delivery methods that suit your learners and use suitable technology to enhance the learning experience. As an example, [transportation and logistics](/industries/transportation-and-logistics/) workers who rarely sit at their desks may come to find a blended learning approach may be more beneficial.
On the contrary, [medical device manufacturers](/training-management-for-medical-devices/) may prefer a more hands-on approach that’s normally found in instructor-led training-based sessions.
8. Select qualified and available training providers
Qualified instructors and trainers are what orchestrate a winning experience for learning academies. As subject-matter experts in their fields, trainers who check all the boxes for instructing learners can turn the most routine course material into an engaging and intellectually stimulating session.
When selecting instructors for ILT or VILT sessions, be sure that they can meet every standard for your training program. From the language of instruction and time-zone coverage to the learner-approved qualities of a good instructor.
9. Don’t forget certification programs!
The best learning academies offer certifications that demonstrate proficiency in a core set of skills. Certifications should be from recognized associations that are from the de jure leaders in their field. For example, People & Culture specialists should aim to receive certs from the Human Resources Certification Institute allowing employees to work toward a certificate to prove their attainment.
Your learning academy team must also have a process in place to make sure that certifications are valid and that expiration dates are noted. Don’t forget to ensure your learners can promote their certification on social media! Besides, who doesn’t like a badge certifying their expertise in a specific ability?
10. Promote the benefits of the learning academy
“If you build it, they will come” sadly doesn’t apply in the world of corporate training. Work with your marketing team, and develop a strategy to get employees excited about the opportunities the learning academy can provide in advancing their development and involvement in the organization. You can even take it a stretch further by promoting your learning academy with partners in your [extended enterprise](/training-management-software-for-extended-enterprise/) that are looking to augment their skills. It’s a win-win for everyone!
11. Create a detailed rollout plan
Once you’re ready to go live, you’ll need a detailed rollout plan to ensure the smooth implementation of your learning academy. This should cover everything from the email and communications plan to creating ambassadors across the business to help encourage enrollment.
This should extend into the first few months after the launch, at which point you can take the first measurements and reassess your promotion plan going forward. Assigning a named owner to each area will help maintain accountability and keep everything moving at the right pace.
Challenges for running learning academies
We don’t want to pretend that running a learning academy is easy. It’s a much bigger undertaking than your standard training course, and it requires ongoing commitment from the entire L&D team.
Some of the key challenges to be aware of when setting up and running learning academies include:
- Understanding the skills needs of your learners and translating them into an actionable course can make it difficult even with a training needs analysis.
- The costs of running a learning academy can be expensive depending on the scope. General Electric’s
[Crotonville Learning Institute](https://hrexecutive.com/the-end-of-ges-crotonville-what-it-says-about-ld/)cost almost $1 billion in management costs. - Managing the logistics of a learning academy is more complex as it has several training programs that can have a significant size and scope of resources
- Managing in-person ILT and online VILT
[course scheduling with spreadsheets](/scaling-training-without-spreadsheets/)can quickly prove to be inefficient and a hassle for your learning academy team.
Bottom line: investing in learning academies means investing in your business growth
As corporate training initiatives grow in importance, learning academies are set to make a comeback for businesses looking to grow and optimize their services. If you’re thinking about developing your learning academy, you must go in with a clear action plan with measurable goals and a deep understanding of your learners’ needs.
A highly effective learning academy requires a blend of eLearning content, on-demand resources, and live ILT or VILT sessions. While asynchronous online learning will help learners access what they need and provide them the opportunity to do it at their own pace, practical skill sets that are used for specific job roles will be best served with ILT and VILT.
Integrating ILT and VILT into your learning academies will help learners make useful connections with their peers, get hands-on with their training, and engage in memorable experiences with inspiring trainers. What’s important, though, is choosing the right technology to help you deliver top-quality live learning experiences with minimal manual effort.
